items.synopsis: Israel says it is at war as its soldiers battle Hamas fighters in the streets of southern Israel and launch air strikes on Gaza. Follow live.

title.children: 'A machine gun started going off': Australian describes fleeing music festival near Gaza

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The United Nations says the number of displaced Gazans has risen to more than 123,000 as a result of the fighting between the Israeli military and Hamas following the militant group’s attack across the border. As of late Sunday (local time), retaliatory Israeli airstrikes had destroyed 159 housing units across Gaza and severely damaged 1,210 others, according to the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs. The UN agency for Palestinian refugees said a school sheltering more than 225 people took a direct hit. It did not say where the fire came from. AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: More than 123,000 Gazans now displaced: UN

children.content: The United Nations says the number of displaced Gazans has risen to more than 123,000 as a result of the fighting between the Israeli military and Hamas following the militant group’s attack across the border.

As of late Sunday (local time), retaliatory Israeli airstrikes had destroyed 159 housing units across Gaza and severely damaged 1,210 others, according to the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs.
The UN agency for Palestinian refugees said a school sheltering more than 225 people took a direct hit. It did not say where the fire came from.
AP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Global affairs editor for ABC News John Lyons has published an analysis piece saying: "Despite Hamas starting this round of attacks, potentially of greater concern to Israel is Hezbollah taking advantage of the crisis." "The immediate military battlelines have been drawn: the United States and Israel versus Iran and Hezbollah," Lyons writes. Read the full analysis column here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Analysis: Hezbollah is a central player in what happens next

featuredLink.title: Israel is facing its most serious crisis in decades — and it will likely get worse before it gets better

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has expressed his "horror and outrage" at the loss of life from "abhorrent" atatcks in Israel. "To see young people chased into the desert and gunned down, to see women and children dragged into the back of vehicles [and] taken hostage is just completely and utterly abhorrent," he said at a press conference in Tasmania. Mr Dutton agreed the acts should be condemned and said Australia should provide "very strong words of encouragement" to Israel and its government which should be "pursuing" the people behind the attacks with "every asset available to them". "When people talk about Israel having to show restraint, it is completely and utterly the wrong time for that sort of language," he said. Watch the press conference below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dutton says taking women, children as hostages is 'utterly abhorrent'

children.content: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has expressed his "horror and outrage" at the loss of life from "abhorrent" atatcks in Israel.

"To see young people chased into the desert and gunned down, to see women and children dragged into the back of vehicles [and] taken hostage is just completely and utterly abhorrent," he said at a press conference in Tasmania.

Mr Dutton agreed the acts should be condemned and said Australia should provide "very strong words of encouragement" to Israel and its government which should be "pursuing" the people behind the attacks with "every asset available to them".
"When people talk about Israel having to show restraint, it is completely and utterly the wrong time for that sort of language," he said.
Watch the press conference below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: One of the big potential talking points of the week is done and dusted just after lunch on day one. Gold Coast have traded picks 4, 46, 51 and a future third rounder to the Western Bulldogs for picks 10, 17 and a future first. Expect picks 10 and 17 to be on the market now, while the Bulldogs have put themselves in a fantastic position in this draft. Someone like Nick Watson could well be the target there.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Western Bulldogs-Gold Coast trade for pick four is done

children.content: One of the big potential talking points of the week is done and dusted just after lunch on day one.
Gold Coast have traded picks 4, 46, 51 and a future third rounder to the Western Bulldogs for picks 10, 17 and a future first.
Expect picks 10 and 17 to be on the market now, while the Bulldogs have put themselves in a fantastic position in this draft. Someone like Nick Watson could well be the target there.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The first trade of 2023 has gone down. And it's a pick swap that will help Port Adelaide chase their many targets this year. Port have sent their future first round pick to Fremantle in exchange for pick 22 and a future second round pick. The Dockers are loading up on 2024 picks. Interesting considering the reports this morning they will be heavily into Logan McDonald next year ...
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Port Adelaide and Fremantle pick trade is in

children.content: The first trade of 2023 has gone down. And it's a pick swap that will help Port Adelaide chase their many targets this year.
Port have sent their future first round pick to Fremantle in exchange for pick 22 and a future second round pick.
The Dockers are loading up on 2024 picks. Interesting considering the reports this morning they will be heavily into Logan McDonald next year ...

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Throughout these trade blogs I'm going to cast an eye over to the draft class of 2023 and a few of the names you'll need to know in the weeks, months and years ahead. And where else to start but Harley Reid? You've probably heard of him already, and are wondering if they incredible hype around this teenager could possibly be justified. I'm here to tell you it is. I saw him play for the first time last year and was completely blown away. Nothing I've seen this season has changed that, and recent performances for Essendon's VFL team and in the Coates League finals for Bendigo have me convinced he's as any draft prospect I've seen for a long time. Reid is the perfect modern-day player, the Martin/Petracca/De Goey prototype who can blitz through stoppages as a midfielder or dominate one-on-one as a forward. His footy smarts are underrated and his skill by hand and foot is fantastic. There are slight concerns over his fitness levels, but from what I saw over the course of the season that improved through the year. No doubt it will improve further on an AFL list. He is an electric footballer, an infectious personality and a player that will get fans through the gates. The hype is real, Harley Reid is very special.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Draft Spotlight — Harley Reid

children.content: (Getty Images)
Throughout these trade blogs I'm going to cast an eye over to the draft class of 2023 and a few of the names you'll need to know in the weeks, months and years ahead.
And where else to start but Harley Reid?
You've probably heard of him already, and are wondering if they incredible hype around this teenager could possibly be justified. I'm here to tell you it is.

I saw him play for the first time last year and was completely blown away. Nothing I've seen this season has changed that, and recent performances for Essendon's VFL team and in the Coates League finals for Bendigo have me convinced he's as any draft prospect I've seen for a long time.

Reid is the perfect modern-day player, the Martin/Petracca/De Goey prototype who can blitz through stoppages as a midfielder or dominate one-on-one as a forward. His footy smarts are underrated and his skill by hand and foot is fantastic.
There are slight concerns over his fitness levels, but from what I saw over the course of the season that improved through the year. No doubt it will improve further on an AFL list.
He is an electric footballer, an infectious personality and a player that will get fans through the gates. The hype is real, Harley Reid is very special.

image.altText: Two election placard - one for yes, one for no

items.synopsis: Follow our live blog for the latest news in the lead-up to voting in the referendum on October 14.

title.children: More than 2.2 million Australians cast early votes in the Voice referendum as Yes campaigners feel the pinch

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A prominent Yes campaigner says if the referendum fails, it will be a "travesty for the country". On Saturday, Australians will be asked whether they support enshrining the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice in the constitution. The majority of polls suggest the referendum will not be successful. Noel Pearson, who is one of the architects of the Uluru Statement of the Heart, which put forward the Voice to Parliament, says that outcome would be disappointing. "This is a moral choice for the country, not just a question of constitutional law," he told AM. "The choice we have is not equivalent - Yes and No are not equivalent choices. "Yes is of a different quality to No. No would be a travesty for the country." You can listen to the full interview on AM with Sabra Lane by taping the link below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Noel Pearson says Australia will never live down a 'No' vote

featuredLink.title: Noel Pearson says Australia will never live down a 'No' vote - ABC listen

props.alt: A close up of Noel speaking.

children.content: Noel Pearson.
(AAP: Lukas Coch)
A prominent Yes campaigner says if the referendum fails, it will be a "travesty for the country".
On Saturday, Australians will be asked whether they support enshrining the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice in the constitution.
The majority of polls suggest the referendum will not be successful.
Noel Pearson
, who is one of the architects of the Uluru Statement of the Heart, which put forward the Voice to Parliament, says that outcome would be disappointing.
"This is a moral choice for the country, not just a question of constitutional law," he told
AM
"The choice we have is not equivalent - Yes and No are not equivalent choices.
"Yes is of a different quality to No. No would be a travesty for the country."
You can listen to the full interview on
AM with Sabra Lane
by taping the link below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Jake Evans Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has rebuffed a former Labor strategist's view the Yes campaign has been defeated. After one poll suggested support had fallen another 2 per cent over the past week to 34 per cent, former Labor strategist and pollster Kos Samaras tweeted the campaign was "over". But asked about Mr Samaras' comment, the prime minister said the campaign was not finished. "It’s only done when people cast their ballots," Mr Albanese said. "We'll wait and see when they cast their vote, I'm not getting ahead of the Australian people — I know some arrogance has crept into the No side campaign."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Not getting ahead': Albanese rejects that Yes vote is sunk

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says he won't pre-empt the votes of Australians at the ballot box this Saturday.
(ABC News:Nick Haggarty)
Reporting by Jake Evans
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese
has rebuffed a former Labor strategist's view the Yes campaign has been defeated.
After one
poll suggested support had
fallen another 2 per cent over the past week to 34 per cent
, former Labor strategist and pollster Kos Samaras tweeted
the campaign was "over".
But asked about Mr Samaras' comment, the prime minister said the campaign was not finished.
"It’s only done when people cast their ballots," Mr Albanese said.
"We'll wait and see when they cast their vote, I'm not getting ahead of the Australian people
— I know some arrogance has crept into the No side campaign."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Casey Briggs The ABC's poll of the polls now puts Yes at an average of 41.2 per cent, well behind No at 58.8 per cent. For Yes, that's well below the level of support that was recorded in the republic referendum in 1999, which failed with just over 45 per cent of the national vote. "I'm old enough to remember that at the time, it didn't feel about a week out that the case for change was in a particularly good place," Professor Simon Jackman from the University of Sydney says. "It sort of feels that way with respect to this referendum too." The model, developed by Jackman, is an effort to understand the polling that has been published, and is not a prediction of the outcome of the vote. Find out more about what polls are telling us about the Voice to Parliament referendum.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What are the polls saying less than a week from the referendum?

featuredLink.title: How is the Voice polling with less than a week to October 14?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some government workers with Services Australia will go on strike today, with other Australian Public Service staff planning industrial action over frustrations their salaries are not keeping pace with inflation. Members of the Community and Public Sector Union (CPSU) will strike for 24 hours from today seeking a better pay offer. The union has rejected the federal government's revised pay offer of 11.2% over three years, saying it doesn't match cost-of-living pressures. "There are very real cost-of-living pressures on workers right across the economy, and the public sector is no different, " said CPSU national secretary Melissa Donnelly. "The Albanese Labor government can and should do better on pay for its own workforce." Ms Donnelly said she expects the strike will impact services like Centrelink. "It is unfortunately likely to have some impact on services across the Services Australia network ," she said. "Be it customers contacting the smart centres, that is the call centres, or people attending in face in service centres." Services Australia is encouraging those who need to access their services and can't delay while the strike is taking place to use self-service: For more about the Services Australia strike, you can read the below analysis from the ABC's Markus Mannheim — he's taken a look at employment data and to try and assess just how much public servants are actually worth.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Happening today: Services Australia workers go on strike

featuredLink.title: How much is a public servant worth? Data suggests it's more than they are paid

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian gold stocks have jumped by as much as 5% today, which is their biggest intraday percentage gain since July 13. It follows strong gold bullion prices and has seen Australian gold prices pushing higher for a second straight trading session. It's also prompted strong performances by gold miners on the market, with Newcrest Mining up by as much as 4.9% — its biggest intraday gain since April 11. Northern Star Resources is also reaping the benefits, climbing by 5.9% for its biggest same-day gain since July 13.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian gold stocks see strongest jump in almost three months

children.content: Australian gold stocks have jumped by as much as 5% today, which is their biggest intraday percentage gain since July 13.
It follows strong gold bullion prices and has seen Australian gold prices pushing higher for a second straight trading session.
It's also prompted strong performances by gold miners on the market, with Newcrest Mining up by as much as 4.9% — its biggest intraday gain since April 11.
Northern Star Resources is also reaping the benefits, climbing by 5.9% for its biggest same-day gain since July 13.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX has extended its early gains into the afternoon, up 0.5% as of 12:55pm AEDT. (If it's live figures you're after, head to the top of the blog.) Energy stocks are continuing to lead the charge for the local sharemarket sectors, up 2.9% off the back of stronger commodity prices due to the Middle East violence. Other sectors in positive territory include basic materials (+0.8%), healthcare (+0.6%) and utilities (+0.4%). Academic and education services are up 0.3%, while financials and technology are a touch higher at 0.1% each. Industrials and consumer cyclicals are flat, while real estate is down 0.6%, and consumer non-cyclicals are down 0.8%. Unsurprisingly, the best performers are mostly gold miners, who are reaping the benefits of higher gold bullion proces. The best performing stocks so far: De Grey Mining +9.2% Evolution Mining +7.3% West African Resources +6.8% Silver Lake Resources +6.3% Regis Resources +5.5% And the worst performers so far: Weebit Nano -9.6% Magellan Financial -5.5% Life360 -2.3% Qantas -2.2% Centuria Capital -1.8%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX extends gains as energy and gold stocks rally on strong commodity prices
